content:
@__hot_town__ in <#1460237271658926144> at <t:1768218095:R>:
>>> Hey Claude Code people,

I'm Vince, Dev Rel for Wasp.sh (fullstack React/Node/Prisma framework with batteries-included), and I'm working hard on an official Wasp plugin for Claude Code.

We want to import some Wasp rules/best practices into Claude's memory after the user installs the plugin and uses it within a Wasp project. Is there any way to package rules or a CLAUDE.md from within the plugin so that it automatically gets added to memory after install?

At the moment, I have a `general-wasp-knowledge.md` doc and a `/wasp:init` slash command that comes with the plugin. The idea is to use the `SessionStart` hook to alert the user to run this command, which just adds an import line to the `general-wasp-knowledge.md` doc in their CLAUDE.md file:
```md
  ‚éø  SessionStart:startup says:
    
     IMPORTANT! The Wasp plugin hasn't been initialized for the current project.
     Run /wasp:init to get the plugin's full functionality -- or reply "opt out" to never see this message again. 
```

I'm wondering if this is a bad practice, or if there's a more efficient way to achieve this result?

content:
I've got a question about prompt engineering. In React (front-end development), you have components which are similar to HTML tags e.g. `<MyComponent>`. 

If I was to write the following in CC: `> I am working with the <Cell> component`

Is there risk that the left and right angled brackets somehow get misinterpreted and not seen as a React component, or lead to bloat while it tries to figure out what the brackets are? Should this be in quotes e.g. `"<Cell>"`?

content: First, please do not tag staff here. They aren't support. Unfortunately, none of the staff or mods here have access to account or billing information and we can't assist with those issues. If you have submitted the ban appeal form as found in <#1114301961831981107> then the Trust & Safety team will respond. It can take some time depending on the level of appeals in the queue. If you don't hear back you can also try emailing support@mail.anthropic.com.

content:
Call me crazy, but I thought the whole point of a status page was to have it display issues automatically, like, every company I've worked for, their status page displayed stats on status based on monitoring scripts and such, so even if everyone was asleep, the page showed an issue, just no this is being addressed message

But Anthropics feels like it's a static html page with some basic JavaScript to show green, until some tech updates it to show red, after people have complained.

It is the most useless status page I have ever seen for any company.
